plausible_answers.text: the objects or phenomena individuated at one level of description

qas.question: Why is materialism is not linked to reduction?

plausible_answers.text: according to which empirical laws and explanations in "special sciences" like psychology or geology are invisible from the perspective of basic physics

qas.question: Why did Jerry Fodor disagree with this view?
What is not a special science?
What level physics does psychology and geology use?

context: Materialism is often associated with <a0_0>reductionism<a0_0/>, according to which <b1_0>the objects or phenomena individuated at one level of description<b1_0/>, if they are genuine, must be explicable in terms of the objects or phenomena at some other level of description — typically, at a more reduced level. Non-reductive materialism explicitly rejects this notion, however, taking the material constitution of all particulars to be consistent with the existence of real objects, properties, or phenomena not explicable in the terms canonically used for the basic material constituents. Jerry Fodor influentially argues this view, <b2_0>according to which empirical laws and explanations in "special sciences" like <b3_0>psychology or geology<b3_0/> are invisible from the perspective of <b4_0>basic<b4_0/> physics<b2_0/>. A lot of vigorous literature has grown up around the relation between these views.
